one_line: Authorizes bonds and revises Mental Health Services Act for treatment/housing.
summary_short_bullets: - $6.38B in state bonds for behavioral health facilities/housing;- Shifts and clarifies MHSA program uses and oversight
summary_detailed: Proposition 1 (2024) packaged a behavioral-health infrastructure bond with updates to MHSA funding and county program rules, aiming to add treatment beds and supportive housing (including for veterans and people experiencing homelessness).
fiscal_impact: Debt service costs over time; repurposes existing MHSA revenues among programs

one_line: Adds explicit right to reproductive freedom (abortion and contraception) to CA Constitution.
summary_short_bullets: - Places reproductive freedom in state constitution;- Does not narrow existing privacy/equal protection
summary_detailed: Prop 1 affirmed reproductive rights in the state constitution, codifying protections for abortion and contraception that already existed in state law.
fiscal_impact: No direct fiscal effect; services already protected in state law

one_line: Would have allowed in-person sports wagering at tribal casinos and certain racetracks.
summary_short_bullets: - Legalizes in-person sports betting under tribal compacts;- Authorizes additional table games (roulette/dice)
summary_detailed: Prop 26 failed; would have permitted in-person sports wagering on tribal lands and limited racetracks subject to regulation.
fiscal_impact: Potential state revenues/costs depending on wagering volume and enforcement

one_line: Would have allowed online/mobile sports wagering statewide under certain partnerships.
summary_short_bullets: - Legalizes online sports betting aligned with tribes/partners;- Creates homelessness fund with revenues
summary_detailed: Prop 27 failed; it would have authorized online sports betting outside tribal lands with regulatory and revenue provisions.
fiscal_impact: Net revenue uncertain; significant regulatory costs offset by fees/taxes if enacted

one_line: Provides additional ongoing funding for arts/music education in K–12 schools.
summary_short_bullets: - Earmarks ~1% of Prop 98 funding increment for arts/music;- Distributes more to low-income schools
summary_detailed: Prop 28 requires a dedicated annual appropriation for arts education above the Prop 98 minimum, with allocations weighted for need.
fiscal_impact: Increases state costs by about $1B annually for arts education

one_line: Would have required on-site licensed medical professional and other rules at dialysis clinics.
summary_short_bullets: - Requires physician/NP/PA on site during treatment;- Ownership disclosure and infection reporting
summary_detailed: Third dialysis initiative (after 2018/2020) also failed; requirements would have increased clinic staffing/reporting.
fiscal_impact: Likely tens of millions in state/local costs if enacted

one_line: Would have added 1.75% tax on income over $2M to fund ZEV programs and wildfire efforts.
summary_short_bullets: - Funds EV rebates/infrastructure;- Funds wildfire prevention/response
summary_detailed: Prop 30 was defeated; it would have raised high-income taxes to fund ZEV incentives/charging and wildfire programs.
fiscal_impact: Increased state revenue $3.5–$5B annually if enacted; funds restricted to programs

one_line: Referendum that upheld the 2020 law banning retail sale of most flavored tobacco.
summary_short_bullets: - Voters affirmed flavored tobacco ban;- Law took effect statewide
summary_detailed: Prop 31 asked voters to approve SB 793’s flavored tobacco ban; “Yes” vote (pass) upheld the law, keeping the ban in place.
fiscal_impact: Minor state enforcement costs; reduced tobacco tax revenue possible

one_line: Classifies app-based drivers as independent contractors.
summary_short_bullets: - Classifies rideshare and delivery drivers as independent contractors;- Guarantees minimum earnings (engaged time) and health stipends;- Adds occupational accident insurance and safety policies
summary_detailed: Prop 22 allowed app-based transportation and delivery companies to treat drivers as independent contractors rather than employees while requiring limited benefits (earnings floor based on “engaged time,” health stipends, and accident insurance). It preempts local rules in conflict and limits legislative amendments.
fiscal_impact: State enforcement and courts costs minor; company-provided benefits funded privately

one_line: Expands California consumer data privacy and creates the CPPA.
summary_short_bullets: - Expands rights (correct, limit “sensitive” data use);- Increases business obligations and enforcement;- Creates California Privacy Protection Agency (CPPA)
summary_detailed: Proposition 24 (CPRA) strengthened and amended the CCPA: it added new rights (like correction and limits on sensitive data), changed thresholds for covered businesses, and created a dedicated state privacy regulator (CPPA) that shares enforcement with the DOJ.
fiscal_impact: Ongoing state costs in low tens of millions annually for new privacy agency

one_line: Referendum that rejected replacing cash bail with risk assessment.
summary_short_bullets: - Referendum on SB 10 risk-assessment system;- “No” vote kept money bail in place statewide
summary_detailed: Prop 25 asked voters whether to uphold SB 10 to replace cash bail with risk assessment. Voters rejected it (“No”), so cash bail remains while related policy debates continue.
fiscal_impact: Potential county jail savings under SB 10 did not occur due to repeal by referendum

one_line: Would have required a physician/clinician on-site at dialysis clinics.
summary_short_bullets: - On-site physician/NP/PA during treatment;- New infection reporting and closure approvals;- Anti-discrimination provisions
summary_detailed: Prop 23 proposed additional dialysis clinic staffing and reporting requirements. Voters rejected it after similar measures failed in 2018 and later in 2022.
fiscal_impact: Increased state/local costs likely tens of millions annually if enacted

one_line: Would have expanded local authority to enact rent control.
summary_short_bullets: - Eases limits of Costa-Hawkins for local ordinances;- Exemptions for newer and single-family owner-occupied units
summary_detailed: Prop 21 sought to allow broader local rent control but maintained certain exemptions. Voters rejected it; state limits on local rent control (Costa-Hawkins) remain.
fiscal_impact: Unknown local government effects; potential private market impacts

one_line: Would have increased penalties for some theft crimes and limited early release.
summary_short_bullets: - Increases penalties for certain thefts;- Narrows early release eligibility;- Expands DNA collection to some misdemeanors
summary_detailed: Prop 20 proposed rolling back parts of prior justice reforms (e.g., Prop 47/57 changes). Voters rejected it, keeping current policies.
fiscal_impact: State/local justice system costs and workload would have increased if enacted

one_line: Changes property tax rules for transfers and inheritance.
summary_short_bullets: - Expands base-year transfer for eligible homeowners;- Narrows parent-to-child reassessment exclusions;- Adds wildfire disaster provisions
summary_detailed: Prop 19 lets eligible homeowners transfer assessed value to replacement homes statewide and limits inherited property tax benefits unless the heir uses it as a principal residence; includes wildfire disaster relief features.
fiscal_impact: Net effects vary by county; some revenue gains from narrowed inheritance rules

one_line: Would have allowed some 17-year-olds to vote in primaries.
summary_short_bullets: - 17-year-olds eligible if turning 18 by general election;- Legislative constitutional amendment
summary_detailed: Prop 18 proposed allowing 17-year-olds who will be 18 by the general to vote in primaries/specials; it failed.
fiscal_impact: Minimal state/county election admin costs if enacted

one_line: Restores voting rights upon completion of prison term (people on parole may vote).
summary_short_bullets: - Restores voting and eligibility to run for office while on parole;- Amends state constitution
summary_detailed: Prop 17 amended the constitution to allow individuals on state parole to vote and run for office; it passed statewide.
fiscal_impact: Administrative workload minor for elections; potential small costs for voter materials

one_line: Would have repealed Prop 209 to allow affirmative action by public entities.
summary_short_bullets: - Repeals 1996 ban on affirmative action in public sectors;- Would permit (not require) considering race/sex in limited contexts
summary_detailed: Prop 16 asked voters to repeal the constitutional ban on affirmative action (Prop 209). Voters rejected it; the ban remains.
fiscal_impact: No direct fiscal effect; indirect impacts uncertain

one_line: Would have created a “split-roll” to tax large commercial property at market value.
summary_short_bullets: - Reassess most commercial/industrial property regularly;- New revenue for schools/local governments
summary_detailed: Prop 15 would have reassessed most commercial/industrial property at market value to fund schools and local governments; voters rejected it.
fiscal_impact: Annual local revenue increase (billions) if enacted; state school funding interactions complicated

one_line: Issues $5.5B in bonds for the state stem cell institute (CIRM).
summary_short_bullets: - Funds research/training/facilities via CIRM;- Adjusts governance and program scope
summary_detailed: Prop 14 authorized $5.5B in general obligation bonds to continue CIRM’s stem cell research and related programs; it passed.
fiscal_impact: State debt service ~hundreds of millions annually over decades

one_line: Would have issued $15B in state school facilities bonds (K-12/UC/CSU/CCC).
summary_short_bullets: - Authorized bonds for modernization/new construction;- Adjusted local bond rules/matching
summary_detailed: March primary school bonds measure failed despite prior similar bonds’ success.
fiscal_impact: Debt service costs over time paid from General Fund if enacted

one_line: Reclassified certain nonviolent offenses from felonies to misdemeanors.
summary_short_bullets: - Reduced penalties for some drug/prop crimes;- Directed savings to treatment/education
summary_detailed: Prop 47 reduced penalties and redirected savings; later debates led to Prop 36 (2024) proposals to increase penalties for some crimes.
fiscal_impact: State/local savings from reduced incarceration; funds redirected per statute

one_line: For reference: changed legislative term limits (not a recent prop but often referenced).
summary_short_bullets: "- Consolidated total service to 12 years in either house",- Context only row (keep or delete as needed)
fiscal_impact: No direct significant fiscal effect

one_line: Guarantees a minimum share of state budget for K–12 and community colleges.
summary_short_bullets: - Establishes Prop 98 formulas and tests;- Continues to govern school funding levels
summary_detailed: Prop 98 set constitutional funding guarantees for schools and community colleges; still central to California budgeting.
fiscal_impact: Allocations vary by Test 1/2/3 formulas; impacts General Fund and Prop 98 reserve

one_line: Temporarily uses new congressional maps (passed by the Legislature in Aug 2025) for CA’s 2026–2030 elections; keeps the independent Citizens Redistricting Commission for maps starting in 2031; expresses support for independent, nonpartisan commissions nationwide.
summary_short_bullets: • Response to Texas’ mid-decade partisan redistricting; • Requires Legislature’s Aug 2025 congressional maps for CA elections through 2030; • Retains California’s independent Citizens Redistricting Commission and directs it to resume in 2031; • States policy preference for fair, independent, nonpartisan redistricting nationwide.
summary_detailed: Proposition 50 is a Legislative Constitutional Amendment responding to other states’ mid-decade partisan redistricting. It temporarily requires California to use congressional district maps enacted by the Legislature in August 2025 for elections through 2030. It retains California’s independent Citizens Redistricting Commission and directs the Commission to resume drawing congressional districts after the 2030 Census and every ten years thereafter. The measure also states California’s support for fair, independent, and nonpartisan redistricting commissions nationally.
fiscal_impact: One-time county costs—up to a few million dollars statewide—to update election materials for the new maps.
